/wiki/Greater_white-fronted_goose: A migratory goose that can travel thousands of miles between Arctic breeding grounds and southern wintering areas, identifiable by its distinctive white forehead patch and salt-and-pepper belly markings. Uniquely, these geese may provide parental care for several years, possibly including grandparenting—an unusual trait among waterfowl.
/wiki/Lesser_white-fronted_goose: A scarce Arctic breeder no bigger than a mallard, this goose sports a distinctive yellow eye-ring and bright orange legs that set it apart from its larger cousins. The critically endangered Fennoscandian population numbers fewer than 100 individuals, making it one of Europe's most threatened waterfowl.
/wiki/Taiga_bean-goose: A massive migratory waterfowl with a distinctive black-and-orange bill, capable of traveling thousands of miles between Arctic breeding grounds and temperate wintering territories. Weighing up to 8.8 pounds with a wingspan exceeding 5.5 feet, this goose produces a loud honking call that echoes across frozen landscapes.
/wiki/Tundra_bean-goose: A migratory arctic goose with a distinctive orange-banded bill, capable of traveling thousands of miles between Siberian breeding grounds and Asian wintering sites. Despite diverging from its taiga cousin 2.5 million years ago, the two species still interbreed, creating a fascinating natural hybrid zone.
/wiki/Pink-footed_goose: An Arctic goose that rarely ventures to North America, with a distinctive bright pink bill and feet. Flocks produce deafening high-pitched honks that can be heard from remarkable distances during migration.
/wiki/Brant_(goose): This diminutive goose dramatically shifted its entire diet in 1931 when eelgrass blight nearly wiped out the population, and has since maintained sea lettuce as a backup food source—a survival strategy still in use nearly a century later. With fewer than 2.2 kg of body mass, it's one of the smallest geese in the world yet undertakes epic Arctic migrations spanning thousands of miles.
/wiki/Barnacle_goose: A striking black-and-white goose that defies nature itself—medieval Europeans believed these birds grew from driftwood like fruit on a tree, complete with shells. In reality, goslings survive cliff falls up to 70 cm high by jumping from mountain nests, with feathery down cushioning the impact as their parents call from below.
/wiki/Cackling_goose: A highly aggressive defender of its territory, this goose can mate for life up to 20 years and weighs as little as 1.4 kg in its smallest subspecies—making it drastically smaller than its Canada goose cousin despite sharing nearly identical black-and-white plumage.
/wiki/Canada_goose: A massive waterfowl with a distinctive black head and white chinstrap, capable of weighing up to 24 pounds and flying at altitudes exceeding 29,000 feet during migration. Known for forming aggressive V-shaped squadrons overhead and defending territory with brutal precision—one documented case saw a male peck a rival's head into mud until it drowned.
/wiki/Hawaiian_goose: Hawaii's state bird nearly vanished entirely, plummeting from 25,000 birds to just 30 by 1952 before a remarkable captive breeding program brought it back from the brink of extinction. This lightweight goose—weighing only 3 to 7 pounds—uniquely mates on land and boasts the longest breeding season of any goose species.
/wiki/Mute_swan: This massive waterfowl can weigh up to 23 kg (51 lb)—making it one of the heaviest flying birds ever recorded—and produces a distinctive vibrant wing-throbbing sound audible from 1-2 km away. Fiercely territorial and highly aggressive in defense of its cygnets, it can overpower and drown even large dog breeds with powerful strikes from its bony wing spurs.
/wiki/Black_swan: A striking all-black waterbird with a brilliant red bill and surprisingly long S-curved neck—one of the longest proportionally among all swans. Though native only to Australia, escaped captive birds have established small populations across the globe, with some colonies in North America numbering in the dozens.
/wiki/Trumpeter_swan: North America's heaviest native bird and largest waterfowl, with a wingspan reaching over 10 feet and weighing up to 38 pounds—nearly extinct by 1933 with fewer than 70 wild birds remaining, but successfully restored to over 46,000 through dedicated reintroduction efforts. Its loud, trumpet-like call can be heard from impressive distances and serves as both a mating duet and predator deterrent.
/wiki/Tundra_swan: An arctic migratory swan capable of flying at altitudes exceeding 26,000 feet, with each individual bearing a uniquely patterned bill that scientists use to track and study individual birds across continents.
/wiki/Whooper_swan: Among the heaviest flying birds in the world, weighing up to 34 pounds with a wingspan exceeding 9 feet. These powerful fliers communicate through deep honking calls and can migrate thousands of miles between breeding grounds and wintering sites.
/wiki/Egyptian_goose: An aggressive African waterfowl now spreading across North America, measuring 25–29 inches long with hidden white wings that flash dramatically during territorial dogfights with rivals. Fiercely protective parents that pair for life and have been observed attacking drones that enter their habitat.
/wiki/Common_shelduck: A striking Eurasian waterfowl that rarely ventures to North America, recognizable by its reddish-pink bill, white body, chestnut patches, and dark green head. Moulting flocks can gather in massive numbers exceeding 100,000 individuals on coastal mudflats.
/wiki/Muscovy_duck: A muscular waterfowl with a bare, warty face that can weigh up to 15 pounds—about twice as heavy as a mallard—and possesses a helical penis capable of extending 7 inches in just 0.3 seconds. These aggressive ducks thrash violently during mating and often roost in trees at night, making them surprisingly acrobatic despite their substantial bulk.
/wiki/Wood_duck: One of the most colorful North American waterfowl, this perching duck is the only duck species capable of producing two broods in a single season and features sharp claws that allow it to roost in trees like no other duck.
/wiki/Baikal_teal: This striking Asian duck breeds across eastern Siberia and winters in East Asia, making a remarkable recovery from near extinction with populations soaring from hundreds of thousands in the 2000s to over 1 million individuals by 2010.
/wiki/Garganey: A nimble dabbling duck that rises from water with twisting, wader-like flight and migrates across entire continents—traveling from European breeding grounds to Africa, India, and Australasia each winter. Males sport a striking brown head with white eye-crescents and produce a distinctive crackling mating call.
/wiki/Blue-winged_teal: A diminutive dabbler that completes one of the longest migrations of any duck, traveling from northern prairies to Central and South America. Males depart breeding grounds weeks before females, making fall flocks conspicuously female-heavy by mid-September.
/wiki/Cinnamon_teal: Males sport brilliant cinnamon-red plumage and can molt three times in their first year alone. These dabbling ducks migrate between North America and South America, with some high-altitude Andean populations living at elevations of 3,500–4,600 meters.
/wiki/Northern_shoveler: This nimble dabbler uses a specialized spatula-shaped bill equipped with comb-like filters to skim crustaceans and plankton from water surfaces, giving it a competitive advantage over other puddle ducks. Populations have soared to over 5 million birds, trailing only mallards and blue-winged teal in North American duck abundance.
/wiki/Gadwall: A dabbling duck that dives more proficiently than its relatives and boldly steals food from diving birds like coots. One of North America's most hunted waterfowl, with approximately 1.7 million shot annually, yet populations continue to grow at 2.5% over nearly 50 years.
/wiki/Falcated_duck: An elegant Asian dabbler with sickle-shaped tertials that hang gracefully from its back, this bird occasionally wanders to North America—though most sightings are escaped captives rather than true vagrants. Ancient hybridization with gadwalls has left its genetic fingerprints in North American populations, even today.
/wiki/Eurasian_wigeon: A highly vocal dabbling duck that migrates between the Arctic and Africa, the male's brilliant white wing patch and chestnut head are unmistakable in flight. Known to hybridize with its American cousin and form massive flocks during winter, reaching weights up to 1,073 grams.
/wiki/American_wigeon: Known for its cream-colored cap and green eye mask, this dabbling duck is a cunning "poacher" that steals vegetation brought to the surface by diving birds—earning it the nickname "robber duck." With a largely vegetarian diet and distinctive three-note whistle, it forms flocks of millions across North America.
/wiki/Pacific_black_duck: A dabbling duck that feeds by upending in the water to reach aquatic plant seeds, but faces extinction in New Zealand due to hybridization with introduced mallards, which possess dominant plumage genes that mask the grey duck's appearance in offspring.
/wiki/Laysan_duck: This flightless dabbler nearly vanished entirely—reduced to just 12 individuals in 1912—but has made a remarkable comeback through dedicated conservation efforts. Once widespread across Hawaii, it now survives only on three remote atolls where it hunts brine flies with a distinctive high-speed snapping sprint.
/wiki/Hawaiian_duck: This secretive island duck is 20-30% smaller than its mainland mallard cousins and produces a softer quack, but poses a unique conservation puzzle: it readily interbreeds with feral mallards to create fully fertile hybrids, threatening its genetic survival with only about 2,000 pure individuals remaining on Kauai.
/wiki/Eastern_spot-billed_duck: A dabbling duck that has expanded its range northward by over 500 km since the early 20th century, possibly in response to global warming. Distinguished by its yellow-tipped black bill and blue-bordered white wing speculum, this species measures 55–63 cm in length and weighs up to 1,500 grams.
/wiki/Mallard: This dabbling duck can hybridize with over 40 different species in the wild, producing fertile offspring that threaten indigenous waterfowl populations. Capable of flying 50-60 days after hatching, the mallard's ducklings are born ready to swim and can survive in nearly any freshwater habitat across the globe.
/wiki/Mexican_duck: A dabbling duck nearly indistinguishable from female mallards, but threatened by hybridization with the more adaptable mallard species—a fate that could erase this bird as a distinct species within decades without conservation intervention.
/wiki/American_black_duck: The heaviest dabbling duck in its genus, weighing up to 3.6 pounds, this eastern waterfowl is known for regularly hybridizing with mallards—a trait so common that some scientists debate whether it deserves to be its own species.
/wiki/Mottled_duck: A non-migratory dabbling duck so prized by hunters that approximately 1 in every 20 individuals is banded—making it one of the most frequently banded waterfowl along the Gulf of Mexico coast. Despite its rarity as a distinct species, it remains genetically vulnerable to hybridization with invasive mallards.
/wiki/White-cheeked_pintail: Distinguished by pristine white cheeks contrasting with its brown plumage, this dabbling duck filters aquatic plants and seeds from brackish waters across the Caribbean and Galápagos with surprising grace. A popular aviary escape, the species occasionally appears in semi-wild flocks across Europe.
/wiki/Northern_pintail: A sleek dabbling duck distinguished by its impossibly long neck and pointed tail feathers, capable of reaching food 12 inches deep on the lake bottom where other ducks cannot. Males clock in at speeds exceeding most waterfowl, with a distinctive chocolate-brown head and white breast that makes them unmistakable in flight.
/wiki/Green-winged_teal: The smallest North American dabbling duck, capable of the fastest growth rate of all duck species—young fledge in just 34-35 days. Forms massive flocking formations in flight that twist and turn with wader-like precision, making it one of North America's most abundant waterfowl.
/wiki/Canvasback: North America's largest diving duck, featuring a distinctive wedge-shaped head and canvas-like white back. This adaptable hunter can switch its diet entirely to Baltic clams when preferred vegetation disappears, a survival strategy that helped it recover from a population collapse of 78% between the 1950s and 1980s.
/wiki/Redhead_(bird): A diving duck with a striking copper head and bright blue bill, capable of switching its entire diet between breeding and wintering seasons—eating mostly insects and mollusks in summer, then switching to aquatic plants in winter. Despite their beauty, redheads are notorious nest parasites, laying eggs in other ducks' nests and reducing hatching success of host species.
/wiki/Common_pochard: A swift diving duck capable of reaching speeds of 49–54 mph in direct flight, this bird doubles its feeding efficiency by gleaning food items that drift away from swans trampling the lake bottom.
/wiki/Ring-necked_duck: A diving duck deceptively named for a neck-ring so subtle it's rarely visible, earning it the alias "ringbill." Despite weighing less than 2 pounds, these small waterfowl migrate thousands of miles between northern breeding grounds and southern winter territories.
/wiki/Tufted_duck: A diminutive diving duck with a distinctive head tuft and population of nearly one million, capable of diving deep to feed on mollusks and aquatic insects both day and night.
/wiki/Greater_scaup: A diving duck capable of plunging up to 20 feet underwater and holding its breath for nearly a minute, allowing it to feast on mollusks and aquatic plants unreachable by other ducks. Forms massive 'rafts' numbering in the thousands during winter migration.
/wiki/Lesser_scaup: A prolific diving duck with a population once numbering 6.9 million that has mysteriously declined by over half since the 1970s, despite remaining North America's most abundant diving duck species. Males sport an iridescent black head with a distinctive small hindcrown tuft and can be identified by their purple-sheened plumage and notably smaller, straighter bill compared to their greater scaup cousins.
/wiki/Steller's_eider: The smallest and fastest-flying of all eider species, this Arctic diving duck can plunge to depths of 30 feet while hunting for mobile prey like crustaceans. Once hunted legally, the Alaska-breeding population has dwindled to less than 1% of the global total, making it one of North America's rarest waterfowl.
/wiki/Spectacled_eider: A master deep-diver capable of remaining submerged longer than most ducks, identifiable by the striking white circular eye patches that resemble spectacles. Once bred across Alaska from the Nushagak Peninsula to Barrow, the population has plummeted over 96% and now numbers fewer than 4,000 nesting pairs.
/wiki/King_eider: A striking Arctic sea duck with a distinctive orange crown-like knob above the male's bill, capable of diving to great depths to hunt benthic invertebrates including sea urchins and starfish. Males sport remarkable multicolored plumage reminiscent of royal robes, while wintering flocks can exceed 100,000 birds.
/wiki/Common_eider: A massive sea-duck capable of flying at speeds up to 113 km/h (70 mph), famous for its incredibly soft down feathers plucked from the female's breast to line nests—the same down that has been harvested for centuries to fill pillows and quilts.
/wiki/Harlequin_duck: A brilliantly patterned sea duck named for the colorful Harlequin character, with densely packed feathers that make it bounce like a cork after diving. Males display elaborate slate-blue plumage with white markings and chestnut patches, while their exceptional buoyancy allows them to thrive in the coldest, choppiest waters of North America.
/wiki/Labrador_duck: A mysterious sea duck with a uniquely flattened bill adapted for probing shellfish from shallow waters, now extinct since 1878—the first known endemic North American bird species to vanish after European contact. Only 55 museum specimens remain worldwide.
/wiki/Surf_scoter: A diving sea duck that can plunge underwater to feed on mussels and other mollusks, with males displaying striking white patches on their head and a uniquely patterned bill in shades of orange, white, red, and yellow. Despite a 50-70% population decline over the past 40 years, this species maintains a global population between 250,000 and 1.3 million individuals.
/wiki/Velvet_scoter: A large dark sea duck that dives deep for crustaceans and mollusks, distinguished by the striking white eye-patches and wing patches on males and their bulbous yellow bill. At 51-58 cm, it's the largest scoter species and forms tightly-packed flocks that take off in unison from coastal waters.
/wiki/White-winged_scoter: A powerful diving duck with a gizzard comprising 8% of its body mass—hard enough to crush the shells of clams and mollusks. Some females can end up tending to as many as 40 ducklings due to brood mixing on crowded breeding grounds.
/wiki/Stejneger's_scoter: This sea duck sports a distinctive tall knob at the base of its orange-yellow bill and a long, elegant "Roman nose" profile reminiscent of a common eider. Forms massive, tightly-packed flocks on coastal waters that take off together in coordinated waves.
/wiki/Common_scoter: A bulky sea duck with an all-black male and a distinctive bulbous bill, known for forming massive tightly-packed flocks that dive and take off in perfect synchronization. In 19th-century France, these birds were so abundant on the coasts and caught in such numbers that the Catholic Church exempted them from Friday fasting rules due to their fishy flavor.
/wiki/Black_scoter: A bulky sea duck with an unmistakable swollen yellow bill, the male is entirely black while diving for crustaceans and molluscs in coastal waters. Nests later than most North American ducks, with females brooding their young for about 3 weeks before the chicks must fend for themselves.
/wiki/Long-tailed_duck: This arctic sea duck is a master deep diver, capable of plunging to depths of 200 feet using its wings like velvet scoters to reach mollusks far below the surface. Males produce a distinctive musical yodeling call that echoes across frozen northern waters.
/wiki/Bufflehead: One of North America's tiniest ducks, weighing just 13 ounces, this hyperactive diver nests exclusively in old woodpecker holes and arrives at wintering grounds with remarkable punctuality year after year. Its bulbous head can swell dramatically larger when males puff out their feathers during displays.
/wiki/Common_goldeneye: A diving duck with brilliant golden-yellow eyes that hunts up to 65 feet underwater, consuming a diet that shifts seasonally from insects to crustaceans depending on availability. Males perform elaborate courtship displays and aggressively defend territory despite weighing just 2.2 pounds.
/wiki/Barrow's_goldeneye: A diving duck that stays flightless for up to 40 days while molting, relying on deep-water mussel beds to survive the vulnerable period. Males defend their territories with aggressive displays lasting around 6 minutes each.
/wiki/Smew: A striking black-and-white diving duck with a distinctive "cracked ice" pattern, equipped with a hooked, serrated bill that makes it a precision fish-hunter capable of diving to snatch prey underwater. Males are unmistakable with their panda-like appearance, while females wear subtle chestnut crowns.
/wiki/Hooded_merganser: A sleek diving duck with an iconic raised crest and a specialized serrated bill for hunting fish underwater. Males display striking black and white plumage during breeding season, while both sexes are adept sight-hunters capable of diving to pursue aquatic prey at depths.
/wiki/Common_merganser: A large diving duck with a serrated bill that acts like a saw to grip slippery fish prey. Known to form crèches where single females have been observed caring for over 70 ducklings at once, reaching speeds of up to 60-70 days to fledging.
/wiki/Red-breasted_merganser: The fastest duck ever recorded, clocking an airspeed of 100 mph while being chased by an airplane—nearly 40% faster than the previous record holder. Armed with a saw-like serrated bill, this diving specialist hunts slippery fish underwater and is the only merganser to regularly brave saltwater seas.
/wiki/Masked_duck: A secretive diving duck that has remained virtually unchanged for millions of years, serving as a living evolutionary link between primitive and modern stiff-tailed ducks. These tiny waterfowl feed by diving deep to harvest seeds, roots, and aquatic insects from freshwater marshes.
/wiki/Ruddy_duck: A compact diving duck with a distinctive stiff, upright tail and bright blue bill in breeding season, capable of raising broods of 5 to 15 ducklings in dense marsh vegetation. Known for aggressive courting displays and an unfortunate tendency to interbreed with endangered European species.
/wiki/Micronesian_scrubfowl: One of the only birds known to incubate eggs using volcanic heat instead of body warmth, with only 2,000-2,500 individuals remaining in the wild. This accomplished runner can escape predators despite being flightless, using its unusually large yellow legs to creep through forest shadows.
/wiki/Plain_chachalaca: A loud, gregarious game bird that communicates through raucous choruses that sound like men arguing, capable of swift ground escapes and dramatic leaping glides through dense brush. Weighing up to 28 ounces, this 19–23 inch chachalaca displays a striking deep red throat patch during breeding season and can adapt to cleared rainforest scrubland where other forest birds cannot survive.
/wiki/Mountain_quail: This small ground-dweller sports a distinctive topknot that changes color with the seasons and can walk surprisingly quickly through dense brush despite having short, rounded wings. Mountain quail rarely fly, preferring explosive bursts of speed with rapid wingbeats followed by a glide to escape danger.
/wiki/Northern_bobwhite: A master of camouflage that has declined by roughly 85% since 1966, this ground-dwelling quail announces itself with a clear, unmistakable whistle that rises a full octave in pitch—giving it its distinctive "bob-WHITE" name.
/wiki/Crested_bobwhite: A ground-dwelling quail with a distinctive pale crest and marbled black-and-white neck plumage, measuring just 7 to 8.5 inches long. Its loud three-syllable breeding call of 'quoit bob-white' echoes across tropical grasslands where it forages in small flocks for seeds and insects.
/wiki/Scaled_quail: Named for the scaly appearance of its breast and back feathers, this bluish-gray bird sports a distinctive white crest resembling a tuft of cotton. When threatened, it prefers to run rather than fly, and can be found up to 15 miles from the nearest water source.
/wiki/California_quail: California's official state bird, identifiable by its distinctive curved six-feather crest that droops forward. These highly social birds create circular dust bath indentations 2.8–5.9 inches in diameter and explode into rapid flight when startled, a behavior called 'flushing.'
/wiki/Gambel's_quail: A desert sprinter with a distinctive topknot, this bird can move surprisingly fast through brush on foot and prefers to walk rather than fly. Males sport striking copper crowns and black faces with white eyebrow stripes, making them easy to spot in arid landscapes.
/wiki/Montezuma_quail: A stubby, secretive quail that freezes motionless in grass rather than fleeing, sometimes allowing humans to approach within just one meter before exploding into flight with a loud pop. Equipped with unusual sickle-shaped claws, it digs holes up to 8 cm deep to unearth hidden bulbs and tubers that leave telltale signs of its presence.
/wiki/Wild_turkey: Despite weighing up to 24 pounds, this forest bird is an agile flier capable of reaching speeds of 55 mph and can be heard gobbling up to a mile away to announce its presence to rivals and mates.
/wiki/Ruffed_grouse: This woodland drummer creates a thunderous wing-beating display that can be heard over a quarter mile away, starting slow and accelerating into a rapid blur of sound. Despite their camouflage and ground-dwelling habits, they'll explode into flight with deafening wing beats when startled, earning the nickname 'thunder-chicken.'
/wiki/Spruce_grouse: A master of camouflage and deception that lets predators approach within just a few feet before taking flight, relying on immobility rather than speed to survive. Males perform spectacular territorial wing-clap displays loud enough to be heard 150 meters away, producing two sharp cracks just half a second apart.
/wiki/Willow_ptarmigan: Alaska's official state bird, this grouse undergoes dramatic seasonal transformations from brown summer plumage to pure white winter coat. With a population of 40 million across the Arctic, it possesses specialized pectoral muscles that allow chicks to maintain body temperature within just two weeks of hatching.
/wiki/Rock_ptarmigan: A master of camouflage that molts from pure white in winter to brown in spring, this Arctic grouse survives harsh conditions with minimal fat reserves by foraging constantly rather than hibernating. Males perform acrobatic aerial displays with rasping vocalizations that sound like a stick being dragged across a picket fence.
/wiki/White-tailed_ptarmigan: The smallest member of the grouse family at just 11-12 inches long, this alpine specialist undergoes a dramatic seasonal plumage transformation—completely white in winter and mottled gray-brown in summer—to remain perfectly camouflaged year-round. It is North America's only bird to permanently inhabit the alpine zone, surviving extreme cold with feathered feet and nostrils.
/wiki/Greater_sage-grouse: North America's largest grouse, males perform elaborate courtship rituals on breeding leks where dominant birds monopolize up to 80% of mating opportunities. Despite weighing up to 7 pounds, these birds lack a muscular gizzard and cannot digest hard seeds—requiring exclusively soft plant matter and insects.
/wiki/Gunnison_sage-grouse: A third smaller than its greater sage-grouse cousins, this bird was hiding in plain sight until 2000—the first new avian species discovered in the USA since the 1800s. Males gather on leks each spring to perform elaborate strutting displays, but only a handful actually breed, and fewer than 1,800 remain in the wild.
/wiki/Dusky_grouse: A mountain-dwelling grouse with the peculiar habit of climbing higher into forests during winter rather than descending to lower, warmer elevations. Males attract females with deep hooting calls and dramatic short flapping flights across their alpine territories.
/wiki/Sooty_grouse: A forest-dwelling grouse with an unusual winter survival strategy—it ascends to higher altitudes when temperatures drop and can survive on fir needles alone. Males attract females with deep hooting calls that sound like someone striking a quiet drum from high in the trees.
/wiki/Sharp-tailed_grouse: Males perform an elaborate mating dance on communal breeding grounds, stamping their feet up to 20 times per second while inflating and deflating vibrant violet neck sacs to attract females. The provincial bird of Saskatchewan, this medium-sized grouse weighs only 21-31 ounces yet travels across vast prairie ecosystems.
/wiki/Greater_prairie-chicken: Males perform an elaborate two-month mating ritual on booming grounds, inflating orange neck sacs and snapping their tails to compete for dominance—with the top two males claiming 90% of all mating opportunities. Once numbering in the millions across Illinois alone, populations have collapsed to approximately 500,000 individuals today due to the conversion of 95% of tallgrass prairie to cropland.
/wiki/Lesser_prairie-chicken: A striped grouse performer that has lost 85% of its habitat and declined by up to 99% in some regions, now surviving in fewer than 0.1% of contiguous patches large enough to sustain a population. Males gather at traditional leks to perform elaborate courtship displays.
/wiki/Gray_partridge: A rotund gamebird capable of laying up to 20 eggs in a single clutch, with chicks that can only digest insects for their first 10 days of life. Known for its harsh kieerr-ik call and explosive flight pattern when flushed from cover.
/wiki/Ring-necked_pheasant: A flashy game bird originally from Asia, males sport iridescent green heads and long streaked tails accounting for nearly 50% of their body length. When startled, they can burst upward at speeds exceeding 90 km/h while emitting distinctive whirring sounds.
/wiki/Kalij_pheasant: Males display striking glossy blue-black plumage with dramatic regional variations, ranging from white-crested western subspecies to white-tailed eastern varieties, making them one of Asia's most visually diverse pheasants. Originally native to Himalayan foothills, this species was introduced to Hawaii in 1962 and now thrives as an established gamebird population.
/wiki/Indian_peafowl: India's national bird, males grow ornamental trains of over 200 feathers stretching up to 6 feet long, despite weighing only 4–6 kg—yet remain capable of flight. The iridescent blue plumage and elaborate eyespots result not from pigment but from the feathers' microscopic structure.
/wiki/Gray_francolin: A graceful ground-dwelling bird introduced to the Hawaiian Islands, renowned for its loud, distinctive call that echoes across open country at dawn—so musically valued that Indian lovers compare their sweethearts' running gait to its swift, gliding stride.
/wiki/Black_francolin: This explosive gamebird prefers to creep away unseen rather than fly, but when disturbed launches into rapid, direct flight punctuated by graceful glides. Males attract mates with an extraordinary creaking call that echoes all day long during the April breeding season.
/wiki/Red_junglefowl: The wild ancestor of all domestic chickens, this iridescent Southeast Asian bird weighs just 1-1.5 kg but males can grow tail feathers up to 28 centimeters long that shimmer with blue, purple, and green in sunlight. Despite being domesticated 8,000 years ago, wild populations still thrive across Asia with distinctive alarm calls for different predator types.
/wiki/Himalayan_snowcock: An introduced Asian mountain dweller weighing up to 6.8 pounds, it launches itself from clifftops and dives down steep slopes to escape predators. A wild population of 200-500 has thrived in Nevada's high peaks since the 1960s, making it one of America's most successful exotic game bird introductions.
/wiki/Chukar_partridge: A rotund partridge standing 13-14 inches tall with distinctive black and white barred flanks and a striking black necklace marking across its white throat. Young chukars are renowned for their unique wing-assisted incline running, a behavior scientists study as a model for understanding the evolution of bird flight.
/wiki/Erckel's_francolin: Africa's largest spurfowl, standing 15–17 inches tall and renowned for its bizarre territorial call—a rapid, cackling laughter that sounds like a bouncing ball speeding toward a frenzied climax. When threatened, this striped gamebird doesn't flee; instead, it runs uphill to escape predators.
/wiki/Blue-breasted_quail: The smallest true quail species, this ground-dwelling bird can live up to 13 years in captivity despite reaching only 1.5 years in the wild, and is famous among bird enthusiasts for developing over a dozen distinct color mutations including blue, silver, and cinnamon varieties.
/wiki/Japanese_quail: A prolific egg-layer capable of producing up to 300 eggs annually with remarkable feed efficiency. These tiny birds have been selectively bred since the 12th century and now orbit Earth in space stations, where their eggs have successfully hatched in zero gravity.
/wiki/American_flamingo: A brilliant pink wading bird with a specialized salt-filtering beak that can extract nutrients from hypersaline water—and even drink near-boiling water from geysers. Known for elaborate synchronized courtship dances and lifespans exceeding 40 years, among the longest of any bird species.
/wiki/Least_grebe: The smallest grebe in the world at just 8 inches long and weighing less than 7 ounces, this aquatic acrobat can dive for up to 12.5 seconds while hunting prey underwater. Its breeding call sounds eerily like a whinnying horse despite its diminutive size.
/wiki/Little_grebe: Europe's tiniest grebe at just 9-11 inches long, this aquatic acrobat pursues fish and invertebrates underwater with remarkable diving ability, covering its eggs with weeds to outsmart predators.
/wiki/Pied-billed_grebe: A master diver that can submerge for 30 seconds and plunge to depths of 20 feet, this stocky water bird controls its buoyancy by trapping air in its feathers like a living submarine. Known for its reclusive nature and nicknamed the 'hell-diver' for its frequent disappearing acts underwater.
/wiki/Horned_grebe: A master diver equipped with large rear-facing feet for underwater agility, this bird swallows fish whole and has evolved a unique stomach adaptation—a matted plug of feathers that functions as a filter to trap fish bones during digestion. The breeding male's striking red-and-black plumage features prominent erectable "horns" that can be raised and lowered at will.
/wiki/Red-necked_grebe: A vocal diving specialist that can plunge underwater in mere seconds to escape predators, featuring a brilliant rusty-red neck during breeding season that transforms to drab grey in winter. Its legs are positioned so far back on its body that it cannot walk on land and must launch itself across water to take flight.
/wiki/Black-necked_grebe: A champion long-distance migrant that travels up to 3,700 miles between breeding grounds and wintering areas, then doubles its body weight during a two-month flightless molt before the journey home. One of the world's most numerous grebes, yet one of the least efficient fliers among all birds.
/wiki/Western_grebe: A swan-necked diving expert that performs one of the most elaborate courtship dances in the waterbird world, with pairs rearing up and pattering across the water's surface in synchronized rushes. This 55–75 cm grebe can weigh up to 2 kg and dives to the lake bottom to hunt fish, impaling smaller prey like a heron.
/wiki/Clark's_grebe: A diving waterbird that closely mimics its western grebe cousin but distinguishes itself with a bright yellow bill and paler plumage extending above the eyes. Known for elaborate courtship displays where pairs perform synchronized rushing and weed-gathering ceremonies to attract mates.
/wiki/Chestnut-bellied_sandgrouse: A desert wanderer capable of traveling up to 50 miles in a single day to find water, this bird is so difficult to keep in captivity that it repeatedly crashes into enclosure walls from sheer panic.
/wiki/Rock_pigeon: Descended from wild rock doves domesticated up to 5,000 years ago, these common urban birds form the majority prey for peregrine falcons in cities, making up to 80% of their diet. Capable of drinking continuously without tilting their heads back, unlike most other birds.
/wiki/Scaly-naped_pigeon: A large slate-grey pigeon with distinctive maroon plumage and a scaly-textured nape, measuring 14–16 inches and featuring striking red eyes surrounded by bare skin patches that differ in color between males and females.
/wiki/White-crowned_pigeon: A fruit-loving pigeon weighing up to 10.6 ounces with a brilliant white crown that shimmers with iridescent green in sunlight. Despite being depicted by John James Audubon in the 1800s, illegal hunting and mangrove deforestation threaten this Caribbean wanderer so severely that abandoning its nest at the slightest disturbance has become its primary survival strategy.
/wiki/Red-billed_pigeon: A robust slate-gray pigeon with a distinctive maroon head and a piercing call that rises in pitch, capable of producing a loud clapping noise with its wings upon takeoff.
/wiki/Plain_pigeon: A large Caribbean pigeon standing 38 cm tall with striking red-wine coloring on its head and breast that contrasts sharply against pale blue-gray plumage. The Puerto Rican subspecies was nearly extinct in the 1970s but was saved through dedicated conservation efforts and now numbers several thousand individuals.
/wiki/Band-tailed_pigeon: North America's largest native pigeon, weighing up to 18 ounces with a distinctive pale tail band and iridescent green neck plumage. This species is the closest living relative of the extinct passenger pigeon and may hold the key to resurrecting that species through genetic restoration.
/wiki/Oriental_turtle-dove: An Asian dove that rarely ventures to North America, distinguished by its distinctive four-syllable 'her-her-oo-oo' call and black-and-white striped neck patch made of silver-tipped feathers. Multiple broods may be raised in a single season, with both parents sharing incubation duties and feeding altricial chicks with nutritious crop milk.
/wiki/Philippine_collared-dove: A brownish dove with a distinctive short collar of dark scales and a loud, melancholy three-note call that echoes across open fields. Once considered a subspecies, it now competes fiercely with introduced Spotted doves and Red collared doves for survival in its native Philippine range.
/wiki/Eurasian_collared-dove: An invasive colonizer that spread from fewer than 50 escaped birds in the Bahamas in 1974 to nearly every US state, expanding at over 100 km per year—more than double its European invasion rate. Known to form winter flocks exceeding 10,000 individuals around grain supplies.
/wiki/African_collared-dove: A small dove measuring just 26 cm with pinkish plumage that serves as the wild ancestor of the domestic Barbary dove, capable of hybridizing to produce new color variations in captive populations.
/wiki/Spotted_dove: An introduced Asian dove that has established thriving populations across parts of North America, recognizable by its distinctive black neck collar with white spots and long tail with white-tipped feathers. Despite their peaceful appearance, they're considered a hazard on airfields due to their habit of flushing into the air when disturbed, sometimes colliding with aircraft.
/wiki/Shy_ground-dove: A shy ground-dwelling dove found exclusively in Pacific island territories, this elusive species has become increasingly threatened by habitat loss and is now classified as Vulnerable across its range.
/wiki/White-throated_ground-dove: A shy forest dweller weighing less than 5 ounces, the male sports a striking chocolate-brown body with pure white head and breast while females remain cryptically brown. Mates for life and produces only a single egg per breeding season, making this ground dove particularly vulnerable to predation from invasive species.
/wiki/Diamond_dove: One of Australia's smallest pigeons at just 19-21 centimeters long, weighing only 35 grams, yet remarkably tolerant of extreme heat through specialized adaptations. Its wings produce distinctive whistling "frrr" sounds in flight, and it communicates through mournful, soft coos that carry a pleasant falsetto quality.
/wiki/Zebra_dove: A diminutive dove measuring just 20-23 centimeters that produces the softest, most pleasant staccato cooing calls in the avian world, inspiring competitive singing contests throughout its range. Its intricate black-and-white barred plumage provides such effective camouflage on the ground that these birds seem to vanish among bare earth and short grass.
/wiki/Passenger_pigeon: Once numbering around 3 billion, this swift flyer could reach speeds of 100 km/h and darken the sky in massive migratory flocks—until intensive 19th-century hunting drove it to complete extinction by 1914, making it a sobering example of human-caused species loss.
/wiki/Inca_dove: A slender desert dove weighing less than 2 ounces that produces a distinctive rattling noise upon takeoff. During harsh winters, these birds stack into pyramids of 10 or more to share body heat and survive the cold.
/wiki/Common_ground_dove: North America's tiniest dove, weighing less than 1.5 ounces yet capable of raising 2-3 broods per year. Its chestnut wing feathers only reveal themselves in flight, making this ground-dwelling sprite nearly invisible until it takes to the air.
/wiki/Ruddy_ground_dove: A diminutive dove weighing barely 1.7 ounces, this species demonstrates remarkable adaptability by thriving in cities and farmland across the Americas. Males engage in aggressive territorial disputes by striking rivals with their wings while displaying striking cinnamon and black underwings.
/wiki/Ruddy_quail-dove: A rust-colored ground forager measuring just 19–28 cm, this quail-dove's russet plumage and distinctive facial mask make it a striking inhabitant of Central and South American forests. Despite being a skilled seed-eater, it remains sensitive to habitat fragmentation and only occasionally strays north to the southern United States.
/wiki/Key_West_quail-dove: A small ground-foraging dove distinguished by its striking rust-colored plumage and bold white facial stripe, with iridescent bronze-green and purplish-red markings on its crown and back. Once bred throughout the Florida Keys but now only appears as an occasional vagrant.
/wiki/Bridled_quail-dove: A ground-foraging dove weighing just 7-8 ounces, distinguished by a bold white facial stripe and iridescent green head in males. This rare Caribbean specialist has been documented hunting and consuming small lizards while probing leaf litter on the forest floor.
/wiki/White-tipped_dove: A territorial dove weighing just 5.5 ounces that announces itself with a distinctive deep hollow call: ooo-wooooo. Despite its small size, it defends its woodland home fiercely and remains a resident year-round, never migrating.
/wiki/White-winged_dove: Identifiable by the brilliant white crescent patch on its wings, this adaptable dove can fly 25+ miles to find water but survives solely on moisture from saguaro cactus fruit. The second most hunted game bird in the United States, with over 1.6 million taken annually.
/wiki/Zenaida_dove: The national bird of Anguilla, this swift-winged dove is distinguished by a white trailing edge on its wings visible only in flight. Capable of raising up to 4 broods per year, it feeds its young with nutrient-rich pigeon milk regurgitated from its crop.
/wiki/Mourning_dove: A prolific breeder capable of raising up to six broods in a single year, with wings that whistle audibly during takeoff and landing. One of North America's most abundant birds, with 20–70 million shot annually by hunters while the population sustains itself.
/wiki/Many-colored_fruit-dove: This entry is not applicable for a North American wildlife Pokédex, as the Many-colored Fruit-dove is endemic to South Pacific islands including Fiji, Samoa, and Tonga.
/wiki/Crimson-crowned_fruit-dove: A solitary fruit-eating dove with a distinctive crimson crown, typically seen alone or in pairs across Pacific island forests where it feeds on figs and tropical fruits.
/wiki/Mariana_fruit-dove: This 24 cm emerald-feathered dove is the official bird of the Northern Mariana Islands and once thrived across the Pacific until invasive brown tree snakes decimated its population—now extinct on Guam since 1984 and surviving only through desperate captive breeding efforts.
/wiki/Pacific_imperial-pigeon: A widespread Pacific fruit-eating pigeon that travels between islands in large flocks to feast on fruiting trees, weighing only 370-420 grams despite its 36-41 cm length. Known to the people of Niue as 'Lupe,' this species was hunted in prehistoric times using elaborate stone platform traps of considerable cultural significance.
/wiki/Greater_ani: A gregarious black cuckoo that nests communally with up to five pairs sharing a single nest and incubating eggs together, with some females even parasitically laying eggs in rival nests—around 15% do so when their own clutches are lost to predation.
/wiki/Smooth-billed_ani: A gregarious black bird that nests communally with up to 29 eggs in a single nest, with young from earlier broods helping to feed their siblings. Despite its weak flight, it excels at foraging for termites, insects, and occasionally ticks from grazing cattle.
/wiki/Groove-billed_ani: A sleek black tropical bird with a massive curved beak carved with distinctive lengthwise grooves, this ani lives in cooperative groups where up to five breeding pairs share a single territory and raise their young communally in one nest.
/wiki/Greater_roadrunner: This ground-dwelling cuckoo can sprint at speeds up to 26 mph, making it the fastest running bird in existence—yet it still prefers to flee on foot rather than take wing. Armed with a keen eye and lightning reflexes, it hunts venomous rattlesnakes, tarantulas, and scorpions without hesitation.
/wiki/Common_cuckoo: A cunning brood parasite that lays eggs mimicking those of 100+ host species, with females capable of visiting up to 50 nests in a single breeding season. Hatched chicks possess remarkable strength to eject host eggs from the nest within hours.
/wiki/Oriental_cuckoo: A secretive brood parasite that travels thousands of miles from Russia to Australia, laying eggs in the nests of warblers and other small birds while the host species unknowingly raises its young. Males announce their presence with a distinctive paired 'poo-poo' call that mimics the hoopoe.
/wiki/Chestnut-winged_cuckoo: A deceptive brood parasite that lays nearly spherical eggs in the nests of laughingthrush birds, relying on unsuspecting hosts to raise its young. This 47 cm crested cuckoo migrates thousands of miles between the Himalayas and Southeast Asia each year.
/wiki/Dark-billed_cuckoo: A sleek insect-hunter measuring just 25-28 cm with a distinctive black mask and citron-yellow eye-ring, capable of asynchronous hatching that allows larger chicks to dominate smaller siblings in the nest.
/wiki/Yellow-billed_cuckoo: A master of rapid reproduction, this bird can transform from egg to fledgling in as little as 17 days, with chicks able to fly within a week of hatching. Known for calling on hot days to presage approaching thunderstorms, earning it the folk names 'rain crow' and 'storm crow.'
/wiki/Mangrove_cuckoo: Despite its scientific name meaning "small," this is the largest of North America's three Coccyzus cuckoos, measuring up to 13 inches long with a distinctive black facial mask and buffy underparts. Known for its guttural "gawk gawk gawk" call, it hunts caterpillars and grasshoppers among the mangrove trees where it nests just meters above the water.
/wiki/Black-billed_cuckoo: This nomadic insectivore can consume toxic spongy moth caterpillars that most birds cannot eat, shedding its stomach lining to disgorge indigestible hairs like an owl. It beats tent caterpillars against branches and can flock to outbreak areas from great distances, increasing local populations during peak pest years.
/wiki/Puerto_Rican_lizard-cuckoo: A patient ambush predator that sits motionless for hours before striking, specializing in hunting lizards with its distinctively decurved bill. Named after its haunting ka-ka-ka call, locals believe its cry predicts rain and sounds eerily like a monkey's screech.
/wiki/Long-tailed_koel: This species is endemic to New Zealand and the Pacific Islands, and does not occur in North America.
/wiki/Lesser_nighthawk: This aerial insectivore captures prey mid-flight using a deceptively large mouth equipped with fine hairs, consuming swarms of flies and mosquitoes in the darkness. It cools itself in scorching desert heat through rapid throat vibrations called gular fluttering, a crucial survival trait while brooding eggs exposed to the intense sun.
/wiki/Common_nighthawk: An aerial acrobat that hunts flying insects on the wing with a distinctive booming sound produced by diving at speeds up to 23 km/h, then migrating up to 6,800 kilometers between North American breeding grounds and South American wintering ranges. Despite its name containing 'hawk,' this nightjar is completely harmless and distinguished by its tiny beak that conceals a massive mouth capable of scooping insects from the air.
/wiki/Antillean_nighthawk: A master of aerial acrobatics that pulls dramatic dives just feet from the ground, creating a distinctive booming sound with its wings. This nocturnal insect-hunter emits a sharp pikadik call that echoes overhead, earning it the Taíno name querequequé in the Caribbean.
/wiki/Common_pauraque: A nocturnal nightjar that hunts insects in flight and occasionally runs rather than flies when disturbed. Its wailing call inspired its onomatopoetic name, and males perform elaborate courtship flights while producing whip-like sounds around females.
/wiki/Common_poorwill: The only bird known to enter torpor for extended periods lasting weeks to months, allowing it to survive harsh winters in a hibernation-like state while concealed in rock piles. This 7-inch nocturnal insectivore gets its name from its distinctive three-syllable call: 'poor-will-low.'
/wiki/Chuck-will's-widow: A nocturnal master of camouflage that swallows small birds and bats whole, this largest North American nightjar hunts with silent wings and announces itself with a slow, vibrating call that sounds like its own name.
/wiki/Buff-collared_nightjar: A nocturnal aerial hunter that forages up to 33 feet in the air, always returning to the same perch between strikes. Males perform elaborate dawn and dusk songs featuring a distinctive "cuk-a-cheea" call that accelerates and drops suddenly.
/wiki/Eastern_whip-poor-will: A master of camouflage that hunts insects in complete darkness, this bird's distinctive call has inspired centuries of folklore claiming it can sense departing souls. Populations have declined over 60% since 1970, making its haunting nighttime song increasingly rare.
/wiki/Mexican_whip-poor-will: A nocturnal insect-hunter heard far more often than seen, this small nightjar weighs just 45-50 grams but fearlessly hunts moths and beetles by sallying through the night air. Its distinctive call—a lazy, lower-pitched version of its eastern cousin's famous 'whip-poor-will'—echoes through southwestern forests and woodlands.
/wiki/Puerto_Rican_nightjar: A ghost-like nocturnal hunter weighing barely 40 grams, this tiny nightjar nearly vanished from existence before being rediscovered in 1961 after presumed extinction. Armed with stiff bristles around its beak, it plucks flying insects from the darkness with surgical precision while camouflaged in cryptic brown and gray plumage.
/wiki/White-tailed_nightjar: A nocturnal hunter weighing less than 1.5 ounces, the White-tailed Nightjar executes acrobatic hunting dives from the ground to snatch insects mid-flight. Males perform a distinctive wing-clapping display and sing throughout the night with a high, piercing call that rises and falls like a drawn-out whistle.
/wiki/Gray_nightjar: This species is not found in the United States or North America and cannot be included in a North American wildlife Pokédex.
/wiki/Northern_potoo: A master of stillness, this nocturnal hunter perches motionless for hours before sallying out to snatch large insects mid-flight. With a distinctive hoarse call and striking yellow eyes that glow red in the dark, it measures 38-46 centimeters long and lays a single egg directly on a bare branch.
/wiki/American_black_swift: A master of aerial hunting, this swift spends nearly its entire life on the wing, foraging for flying insects while resembling a sleek flying cigar with curved wings. Fewer than 150 breeding sites exist in the United States, with most birds mysteriously wintering in the Brazilian rainforest—a journey tracked for the first time in 2012.
/wiki/White-collared_swift: A master of the skies, this swift reaches speeds of 70-100 km/h while hunting flying ants in flocks of 200 or more, and produces an impressive whooshing sound when rapidly descending through valleys.
/wiki/Chimney_swift: A cigar-shaped aerial acrobat that never lands, drinking and bathing on the wing while consuming 5,000-6,000 insects per day with a wingspan that extends 1.5 inches beyond its tail when folded. This gregarious insectivore roosts in communal colonies numbering in the thousands and migrates annually to South America—a journey so demanding that its weight gain before departure is minimal, requiring refueling stops along the way.
/wiki/Vaux's_swift: A tiny aerial acrobat weighing less than a penny, this swift feeds entirely in flight and can roost on vertical surfaces using specialized claws. Each autumn, up to 35,000 of these birds gather in a single Portland, Oregon chimney in North America's largest concentration of the species.
/wiki/Short-tailed_swift: Not applicable - this species is found exclusively in Central and South America, from Panama through the Amazon Basin to northern Bolivia.
/wiki/White-rumped_swiftlet: A diminutive aerial acrobat native to the South Pacific, this swift spends nearly its entire life in flight, catching insects mid-air with remarkable precision. Its small size belies incredible speed and agility, making it nearly invisible as it darts through tropical forests and rocky outcrops.
/wiki/Uniform_swiftlet: A master of echolocation, this 13 cm swiftlet navigates pitch-black caves with sonar-like precision to reach its moss-and-saliva nests. Weighing just 11 grams, it hunts flying insects at breakneck speeds across Southeast Asian and Melanesian skies.
/wiki/Mariana_swiftlet: This tiny 4.3-inch swift navigates pitch-black limestone caves using echolocation clicks, hunting aerial insects at dawn and dusk in colonies of up to several hundred birds. Once thriving across the Pacific, populations have plummeted to fewer than 7,000 individuals across all remaining territories.
/wiki/Caroline_Islands_swiftlet: Endemic to the Caroline Islands, this tiny swift is perfectly adapted for life in the air, spending most of its day catching insects mid-flight with incredible agility and precision.
/wiki/Common_swift: A tireless aerial acrobat that spends up to 10 months in continuous flight without landing, covering millions of kilometers over its lifetime while hunting insects on the wing at speeds exceeding 69 mph.
/wiki/Pacific_swift: An almost entirely airborne bird that may even sleep while flying, this swift hunts insects at heights up to 980 feet while circling in flocks of tens of thousands, powered by a 43-to-54-centimeter wingspan.
/wiki/Alpine_swift: An Old World alpine swift found exclusively in Africa, Europe, and Asia—not present in North America. Capable of staying aloft for over 200 consecutive days without landing, performing all vital functions including sleep while flying.
/wiki/White-throated_swift: A blur of black and white that rarely touches ground, this aerial insectivore spends entire days aloft catching flying insects at speeds exceeding 100 mph, bathing and preening mid-flight without ever landing.
/wiki/Antillean_palm-swift: A tiny aerial acrobat weighing less than half an ounce, this swift hunts insects on the wing while producing an almost constant twittering call. It builds elaborate hanging pouch nests from plant fibers glued together with its own saliva, hanging them from dead palm fronds in small colonies.
/wiki/Mexican_violetear: A shimmering metallic green hummingbird with a brilliant violet ear-patch, weighing less than a penny while maintaining a fierce territorial defense of feeding grounds. Males sing the same monotonous call up to 60 times per minute from exposed perches, making them as persistent as they are diminutive.
/wiki/Green-breasted_mango: A jewel-like hummingbird weighing less than a quarter ounce, with males sporting an iridescent bronze-green crown and velvety black throat stripe. This diminutive nectar-hunter can hover at all forest levels and occasionally ventures north to Texas, sometimes traveling thousands of miles from its Central American home.
/wiki/Puerto_Rican_mango: A iridescent bronze-green hummingbird weighing less than a quarter ounce that fiercely defends nectar-rich territories and can forage as high as 66 feet above ground. Males display dark bellies while females sport distinctive white-tipped tail feathers, making this resident Caribbean jewel unmistakable in flight.
/wiki/Green_mango: A jewel-toned hummingbird weighing merely 7 grams that defends flowering trees with fierce territorial displays. Males feature iridescent metallic blue-green underparts and can hover while feeding on nectar and insects caught mid-flight.
/wiki/Purple-throated_carib: A jewel-toned hummingbird weighing less than half an ounce, this Caribbean resident defends flower-centered territories year-round with strident calls and remarkable aerial agility, constructing delicate cup nests from spider silk and plant fibers suspended 10-16 feet above the ground.
/wiki/Green-throated_carib: A iridescent hummingbird with a brilliant green back and gorget, capable of beating its wings up to 80 times per second while defending its flowering feeding territories year-round.
/wiki/Rivoli's_hummingbird: One of North America's two largest hummingbirds, with iridescent violet crown and brilliant blue-green throat that flash only when caught by sunlight. It feeds on insects far more than other North American hummingbirds, hunting them mid-air with surgical precision.
/wiki/Plain-capped_starthroat: A tiny Mexican hummingbird barely larger than your thumb that has colonized Arizona only since 1969, now appearing almost annually. Males sport a brilliant red gorget and defend flower patches with remarkable aggression for a bird weighing just 0.26 ounces.
/wiki/Amethyst-throated_mountain-gem: A brilliant jewel of the mountains, this hummingbird weighs less than a penny yet performs acrobatic aerial displays diving toward females up to five times in succession. Males sport a dazzling rosy-pink gorget that shifts to violet-blue in the rarest subspecies, and both sexes produce complex vocalizations with up to nine distinct phrases.
/wiki/Blue-throated_mountain-gem: The largest hummingbird in the United States, measuring up to 5 inches long with an iridescent cobalt-blue throat patch. Despite weighing less than a penny, it produces ultrasonic vibrations to stun and disorient its insect prey, and can vocalize across an unusually large frequency range of 1.8 to 30 kHz.
/wiki/Bahama_woodstar: One of the smallest hummingbirds in North America at just 3.1-3.7 inches long and weighing less than a dime, this iridescent jewel can produce high-pitched songs lasting 30 seconds while hovering motionless in mid-air.
/wiki/Lucifer_hummingbird: A shimmering desert jewel with a distinctive forked tail and iridescent magenta gorget, males perform elaborate 30-45 second courtship dives that produce sharp snapping sounds from their wings and tail feathers.
/wiki/Ruby-throated_hummingbird: A master of aerobatic flight, this tiny bird achieves heart rates up to 1,260 beats per minute and can fly backward, hover in place, and execute wing beats at 80 times per second. Incredibly, it doubles its body fat before embarking on a nonstop 900-mile journey across the Gulf of Mexico during migration.
/wiki/Black-chinned_hummingbird: A tiny aerial acrobat that dives at speeds reaching 60 feet while producing an audible trill through its feathers. Despite weighing mere grams, it possesses the smallest genome of all living amniotes at just 910 million base pairs.
/wiki/Vervain_hummingbird: The second-smallest bird in the world at just 2.4 inches long and weighing as little as a penny, this hummingbird is the only male hummingbird species that lacks any iridescent feathering. Weighing only 2 to 2.4 grams, it lays eggs smaller than a grain of rice and doesn't defend feeding territories like other hummingbirds.
/wiki/Anna's_hummingbird: This iridescent jewel performs acrobatic courtship dives reaching 385 body lengths per second—faster than a Formula 1 racecar relative to body size—while producing an explosive squeak with its tail feathers. The only North American hummingbird with a crimson crown, it can survive subfreezing winters by entering torpor and has expanded its range northward into snowbound cities.
/wiki/Costa's_hummingbird: A tiny desert jewel barely 3 inches long, this hummingbird mesmerizes females with high-speed diving displays that showcase its vibrant purple throat, producing a high-pitched vibration with its tail feathers as it swoops past.
/wiki/Calliope_hummingbird: The smallest bird native to North America at just 2.8–3.9 inches long, yet undertakes an exceptional 5,000-mile annual migration—making it the world's smallest long-distance migrant. During courtship, males dive at high speed while their tail feathers vibrate at frequencies that produce sonic buzzes and wing beats reaching 95 flaps per second.
/wiki/Rufous_hummingbird: This 3-inch dynamo undertakes a 2,000-mile migratory journey despite weighing only 3-4 grams, and supports itself during hovering with 75% downstroke power while beating its wings at frequencies no other bird can match.
/wiki/Allen's_hummingbird: Weighing less than a penny, this hummingbird performs a frantic 25-foot courtship dive followed by a 100-foot plunge that produces a characteristic sharp tail flutter to attract mates. Despite their tiny size, males are fiercely territorial and have been known to attack hawks and kestrels.
/wiki/Broad-tailed_hummingbird: A tiny aerial acrobat weighing just 3.6 grams that produces a distinctive buzzing wing trill audible up to 75 meters away during courtship dives. Males defend territories fiercely, with those lacking the signature wing trill losing their ground to more aggressive rivals.
/wiki/Bumblebee_hummingbird: One of the smallest hummingbirds in existence, weighing merely 2-2.7 grams and measuring just 2.3 to 3.0 inches long. Its wings beat so rapidly they produce an insect-like buzz audible during courtship displays.
/wiki/Puerto_Rican_emerald: This iridescent jewel weighs barely more than a penny yet possesses remarkable agility, feeding on nectar from a wide variety of flowering plants while also hunting tiny arthropods by gleaning them from leaves and branches. Males dazzle with shimmering bluish-green gorgets and forked steely-blue tails, while their high-pitched trilling song sounds like rapid descending notes followed by lisping calls.
/wiki/Broad-billed_hummingbird: A jewel-like hummingbird weighing just 3-4 grams with a brilliant red bill, capable of hovering motionless and performing acrobatic pendulum displays to attract mates. Its long tongue extends deep into flowers to sip nectar while beating its wings up to 80 times per second.
/wiki/White-eared_Hummingbird: A jewel-sized hummingbird weighing less than a penny, with a brilliant violet forehead and emerald throat that defends feeding territories against much larger hummingbird species through aggressive displays and secretive aerial maneuvers.
/wiki/Xantus's_hummingbird: A jewel-like emerald hummingbird weighing just 3.5 grams with a throat that shimmers iridescent green, capable of defending feeding territories and serving as a major pollinator for desert madrone flowers across the Baja Peninsula.
/wiki/Antillean_crested_hummingbird: One of the few hummingbirds sporting a distinctive metallic crest, this tiny Caribbean jewel holds the distinction of being the first avian species ever documented as prey to a tailless whipscorpion. Males flash brilliant blue-green or golden crests while aggressively defending territory from birds, reptiles, and insects alike.
/wiki/Violet-crowned_hummingbird: A jewel-like wanderer weighing less than a penny, this hummingbird beats its wings up to 80 times per second and can hover motionless while sipping nectar from flowers with its brilliant red bill.
/wiki/Berylline_hummingbird: A tiny emerald jewel weighing merely 4.4 grams, this hummingbird dominates feeding territories with aggressive territoriality and can hover in place by beating its wings up to 80 times per second.
/wiki/Cinnamon_hummingbird: A tiny jewel of a bird weighing merely 5-5.5 grams, yet fiercely territorial—defending its feeding sites from larger bees and butterflies with aggressive precision. Its metallic bronze-green plumage and cinnamon underparts earned it a scientific name meaning 'golden red' in Latin.
/wiki/Buff-bellied_hummingbird: This iridescent jewel weighs less than a penny yet fiercely defends its feeding territory from rivals and insects alike. It hovers while feeding on nectar from dozens of plant species and can disperse hundreds of miles along coastal regions during winter months.
/wiki/Paint-billed_crake: A secretive rail with a striking red and yellow bill that can sing up to 36 rapid-fire staccato notes in a single accelerating series. So elusive that its exact range and abundance remain poorly understood despite inhabiting a vast territory across South America.
/wiki/Spotted_rail: This secretive rail makes a loud, rasping territorial screech that echoes through wetlands at dawn and dusk, despite rarely venturing into the open. Weighing less than half a pound, it hunts invertebrates and small fish while staying hidden in dense marsh vegetation across Central and South America.
/wiki/Rufous-necked_wood-rail: A secretive rail with a distinctive rufous-brown head and neck that hunts primarily for crabs along mudflats and stream banks during twilight hours. Known for its loud, irregularly paced duet calls that echo through mangrove forests at dusk and dawn.
/wiki/Ridgway's_rail: A chicken-sized marsh dweller with a distinctively curved bill, this nocturnal forager probes tidal mudflats for mussels and clams while remaining hidden in dense wetland vegetation, with populations in San Francisco Bay numbering around 1,100 individuals.
/wiki/Clapper_rail: A chicken-sized marsh specialist that rarely takes flight, relying instead on its ability to sprint through dense vegetation on the ground. Despite weighing up to 14 ounces, it uses its long, slightly curved bill to probe for crustaceans and small fish in shallow water, sometimes raising clutches of up to 16 eggs in a single breeding season.
/wiki/King_rail: North America's largest rail species, this diurnal marsh dweller can become completely flightless for nearly a month during its post-nesting molt. A master hunter of shallow waters, it probes mud for aquatic insects with its elegant downward-curved bill while sporting a distinctive rusty-brown face and white throat.
/wiki/Virginia_rail: A secretive marsh dweller with the highest leg-muscle-to-flight-muscle ratio of any bird (25% versus 15%), enabling it to run through dense vegetation on long toes rather than fly. More often heard than seen, this elusive rail produces harsh nocturnal calls and can compress its body laterally to slip through reeds like a feathered ghost.
/wiki/Corn_crake: A master of camouflage that calls out its location over 20,000 times per night during breeding season, with a loud repetitive "krek krek" audible from nearly a mile away. Despite its elusive nature, this secretive rail has inspired countless local names across European folklore.
/wiki/Sora_(bird): A secretive rail that weighs less than 4 ounces but produces a loud, descending whinny call audible across entire marshes—more often heard than seen despite its remarkable boldness in investigating the source of recorded calls.
/wiki/Common_gallinule: A bold wetland wader with a striking red facial shield and yellow legs, capable of walking across lily pads thanks to its uniquely wide feet and sometimes carrying its threatened chicks away to safety by flying while they cling to the parent's body.
/wiki/Eurasian_moorhen: A distinctive rail with jet-black plumage, bright red frontal shield, and yellow legs, capable of carrying its young to safety by having them cling to the parent's body during flight.
